Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: EVOLUTION OF HOST CONTROL OVER SYMBIOSIS, DYSBIOSIS IN ANTHROPOGENIC LANDSCAPES
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rhizobial bacteria are key symbionts that infect the roots of pea plants and their relatives (legumes) and fix nitrogen for their hosts in exchange for carbon. Yet global changes are now altering nutrient fluxes of carbon and nitrogen that are the currency of trade between rhizobia and their hosts. In some soils, nitrogen levels have increased more than 100-fold due to pollution from fossil fuel combustion. Evolutionary theory predicts degradation of host systems that control symbiosis in such extreme settings, potentially unleashing epidemics of exploitative symbionts. This project investigates the rapid evolution of legumes and their symbionts in response to nitrogen pollution. Genetic and phenotypic analyses will resolve differences among populations in California that vary in nitrogen pollution levels and will uncover the extent and molecular mechanisms of rhizobial exploitation.

This project will enhance our understanding of rhizobial symbioses, which are critical to wild plants and provide an important service to the bio-economy via enhanced crop growth and biofuel production. This project will also (i) train middle-school students and directly involve them in gathering data, (ii) develop a college course focused on the scientific method and its application to social and policy-related decisions, and (iii) initiate a microbiology-research training program that targets undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rhizobial bacteria are key symbionts that infect the roots of pea plants and their relatives (legumes) and provide nitrogen fertilization for their hosts in exchange for carbon from photosynthesis. Since industrialization, however, global changes in the atmosphere have altered nutrient fluxes of carbon and nitrogen that are the currency of trade between rhizobia and their hosts. In some soils, nitrogen levels have increased more than 100-fold due to pollution from fossil fuel combustion. Evolutionary theory predicts degradation of host systems that control symbiosis in such extreme settings, potentially unleashing epidemics of exploitative symbionts.

 

This project investigated the rapid evolution of legumes and their symbionts in response to nitrogen pollution. Genetic and phenotypic analyses were used to resolve differences among populations in California that vary in nitrogen pollution levels and to uncover the extent and molecular mechanisms of rhizobial exploitation. We made discoveries both about the bacterial and plant populations that we studied.

 

For the bacteria, we discovered ‘epidemic’ patterns of strain abundance. These patterns - discovered across the state of California - showed that the bacterial symbiont populations are similar to pathogen populations with some strains dominating the landscape.  We discovered that the epidemics are driven by strains with superior catabolic capacity that likely allow them to proliferate in soils. We also discovered that non-beneficial symbionts dominated some host populations, but this occurred independently of soil nitrogen. These discoveries open up new avenues of how to promote plant growth through the application of these strains with superior characteristics.

 

From the plant perspective, we discovered that host control traits were not significantly affected by nitrogen fertilization. Instead, we found strong evidence supporting theoretical work that legumes regulate rhizobial cheaters irrespective of extrinsic changes in carbon and or nitrogen. We found evidence that legume sanctions, the host system to reward good bacteria and punish unhelpful strains, is based purely on the benefits of nitrogen fixation provided directly by the symbiont. These discoveries revealed surprising control over symbionts by plant hosts, control that is relatively unaffected by dramatic changes in our biosphere. These patterns suggest that plants are much more flexible to changes in the environment.


This project greatly enhanced our understanding of rhizobial symbioses, which are critical to wild plants and provide an important service to the bio-economy via enhanced crop growth and biofuel production. This project also (i) trained middle-school students and directly involve them in gathering data, (ii) developed a college course focused on the scientific method and its application to social and policy-related decisions, and (iii) initiated a microbiology-research training program that targets undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in the sciences.
